content: The National Pain Care Policy Act of 2008, also known as the "National Pain Care Policy Act," includes sections on an Institute of Medicine Conference on Pain, pain research at the National Institutes of Health, pain care education and training, and a public awareness campaign on pain management. The Secretary of Health and Human Services aims to convene a Conference on Pain with the Institute of Medicine to address the recognition and management of pain as a public health issue in the US. The Conference will evaluate the adequacy of pain assessment, diagnosis, and treatment, identify barriers to appropriate pain care, and focus on specific demographic groups affected by pain disparities. The lack of understanding and education among employers, patients, health care providers, regulators, and third-party payors, barriers to access to care at different levels, including those specific to undertreated populations, physician concerns over regulatory policies, and gaps in pain research are key issues identified in addressing pain management as a public health concern in the US. The Institute of Medicine may collaborate with other entities if they decline to participate in addressing pain management as a public health concern. A report on the Conference's findings and recommendations is due to Congress by June 30, 2010, with an authorization of $500,000 for fiscal years 2009 and 2010. SEC. 409J. PAIN RESEARCH: Amends the Public Health Service Act to include provisions for pain research at the National Institutes of Health. The Director of NIH is encouraged to expand research initiatives on pain causes and treatments through the Pain Consortium. Annually, the Consortium must develop recommendations for pain research initiatives using reserved funds. The Secretary will establish the Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee to coordinate pain research efforts within the Department of Health and Human Services and other Federal agencies. The Committee will consist of voting Federal representatives. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee will include representatives from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the National Institutes of Health, other relevant national research institutes and centers, selected agencies of the Department of Health and Human Services, and representatives from other Federal agencies involved in pain care research. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee will have voting members appointed by the Secretary, including scientists, physicians, and health professionals from various disciplines. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee will have voting members from various disciplines and geographical regions, including clinical, basic, and public health sciences. Additionally, 6 members will be appointed from the general public, representing research, advocacy, and service organizations for individuals with pain-related conditions. Nonvoting members may also be included as determined by the Secretary. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee will have voting members selecting a chairperson subject to NIH Director approval. Meetings will be held at least once a year, and duties include summarizing pain care research advances and identifying critical gaps in research. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee will identify gaps in pain research, recommend ways to avoid duplication of efforts, disseminate information on pain care, and expand partnerships between public and private entities for collaborative research. The Secretary will review the necessity of the Committee every two years. SEC. 4. PAIN CARE EDUCATION AND TRAINING. Amends Part D of title VII of the Public Health Service Act to include a program for education and training in pain care. The Secretary may award grants, agreements, and contracts for pain care education programs to health professions schools and other entities. Priority is given to program implementation. Recipients must include education on pain assessment, treatment, and laws on controlled substances. Education and training can be provided at health professions schools, residency programs, and other graduate programs. The Secretary evaluates programs in pain care to assess their impact on knowledge and practice. Peer review groups include experts in pain care. Pain care involves assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and management. The text amends section 758(b)(1) by updating references from 754 and 755 to 755 and 756. SEC. 249. NATIONAL EDUCATION OUTREACH AND AWARENESS CAMPAIGN ON PAIN MANAGEMENT. The Secretary must establish a national pain care education outreach campaign by June 30, 2009. The campaign aims to educate the public on the importance of pain management, its consequences, treatment options, and the need for prompt assessment and management. The Secretary must establish a national pain care education outreach campaign by June 30, 2009 to educate the public on the importance of pain management, treatment options, and the need for prompt assessment and management. This includes adjusting treatment as needed, the role of pain management specialists, availability of pain management information and resources, and other relevant issues deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary will consult with various organizations and professionals in designing and implementing the public awareness campaign. A lead official will be designated to oversee the campaign, and coordination with other agencies such as the Surgeon General and the CDC will be ensured. The Secretary will consult with organizations and professionals to design and implement a public awareness campaign. The campaign will address the special needs of underserved areas and populations, aiming to reduce disparities in access to diagnosis, assessment, and treatment. Grants and contracts may be awarded to assist with the campaign's development and implementation. The Secretary will evaluate the public awareness campaign's effectiveness in educating the general public on specific matters by the end of fiscal year 2011. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, and $4,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 24, 2008. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
